snippet: Within a week, Argentinians were told their president had cancer and then that she did not. They deserve an explanation.
abstract: Within a week, Argentinians were told their president had cancer and then that she did not. They deserve an explanation.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES - Last week, I took a look at President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner's cancer diagnosis and how she has personalized power far too much. On Saturday, Argentinians were stunned to learn that, after removing the president's thyroid gland, doctors discovered she didn't have cancer after all but rather a benign tumor. Following the initial relief, doubts quickly set in: despite assurances that such misdiagnoses can happen, many Kirchner critics cited the episode as another example of why the government's words can't be trusted.
